citation.article-title: Desulfobulbus mediterraneus sp. nov., a sulfate-reducing bacterium growing on mono- and disaccharides.

p.s: Description of Desulfobulbus mediterraneus sp. nov.
Desulfobulbus mediterraneus (me.di.ter.ra'ne.us. M.L. adj. mediterraneus from the Mediterranean Sea, pertaining to the habitat the organism was isolated from)
Ovoid cells, 1.2–1.7 μm wide and 1.4–3.2 μm long.
Motile. b and c type cytochromes are present.
One to three flagella are present with terminal to subterminal insertion.
The G+C content of the DNA is 58.6 mol%.
Temperature range for growth is from 10°C to 35 °C with an optimum at 25 °C.
Growth was observed between pH 6.3 and 8.0 and from 10 to 70 g NaCl l–1.

Substrates used for anaerobic respiration are pyruvate, lactate, propionate, malate, succinate, fumarate, ethanol, n-propanol, n-butanol, n-pentanol, alanine, glutamate, ribose, glucose, fructose, galactose, cellobiose, lactose and sucrose.
Pyruvate, lactate, glutamate, ribose, glucose, fructose, galactose, cellobiose, lactose and sucrose can be fermented.
Sulfate, sulfite, and thiosulfate serve as electron acceptors.
Oxygen can be used as electron acceptor, but strain 86FS1 does not grow in the presence of oxygen.
Vitamins are not required, but promote growth.
Type strain: 86FS1, deposited as DSM 13871 with the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen und Zellkulturen (DSMZ, Braunschweig, Germany).
